### Feature Explanation [Original Link to The Dataset](https://data.iowa.gov/Sales-Distribution/Iowa-Liquor-Sales/m3tr-qhgy)
[Link to Google Cloud Platform](https://console.cloud.google.com/marketplace/details/iowa-department-of-commerce/iowa-liquor-sales?filter=category:machine-learning&id=18f0a495-8e20-4124-a349-0c4c167b60ab)

'Invoice/Item Number' - Concatenated invoice and line number associated with the liquor order. This provides a unique identifier for the individual liquor products included in the store order.
'Date' - Date of order.
'Store Number' - Unique number assigned to the store who ordered the liquor.
'Store Name' - Name of store who ordered the liquor.
'Address' - Address of store who ordered the liquor.
'City' - City where the store who ordered the liquor is located.
'Zip Code' - Zip code where the store who ordered the liquor is located.
'Store Location' - Location of store who ordered the liquor. The Address, City, State and Zip Code are geocoded to provide geographic coordinates. Accuracy of geocoding is dependent on how well the address is interpreted and the completeness of the reference data used.
'County Number' - Iowa county number for the county where store who ordered the liquor is located.
'County' - County where the store who ordered the liquor is located.
'Category' - Category code associated with the liquor ordered.
'Category Name' - Category of the liquor ordered.
'Vendor Number' - The vendor number of the company for the brand of liquor ordered.
'Vendor Name' - The vendor name of the company for the brand of liquor ordered.
'Item Number' - Item number for the individual liquor product ordered.
'Item Description' - Description of the individual liquor product ordered.
'Pack' - The number of bottles in a case for the liquor ordered.
'Bottle Volume (ml)' - Volume of each liquor bottle ordered in milliliters.
'State Bottle Cost' - The amount that Alcoholic Beverages Division paid for each bottle of liquor ordered.
'State Bottle Retail' - The amount the store paid for each bottle of liquor ordered.
'Bottles Sold' - The number of bottles of liquor ordered by the store.
'Sale (Dollars)' - Total cost of liquor order (number of bottles multiplied by the state bottle retail).
'Volume Sold (Liters)' - Total volume of liquor ordered in liters. (i.e. (Bottle Volume (ml) x Bottles Sold)/1,000).
'Volume Sold (Gallons)' - Total volume of liquor ordered in gallons. (i.e. (Bottle Volume (ml) x Bottles Sold)/3785.411784).
### <font color='orange'>Data Cleansing</font>

#### Validate The Calculation
Importance about the dataset: some discrenpencies -> sales != state bottle retail*bottles sold.
We have discussed this discrepancy with our DBA who manages the data being sent. They found that the Unit volume was sent instead of bottles. Units can be cases, bottles, or sleeves. We are working to append the sales data to reflect actual bottles. Until then please take Sales/state bottle retail= Bottles sold. This new Bottles sold can be used to find the true liters and gallons sold. The data from September 16' to Current 2018 is affected. We will comment an update when the bottles column has been fixed and the data has been appended.


In 2016 ABD invested into a new all in one system to keep up with demands in technology and sales. Our products team took this as an opportunity to fix our product categories in the database since they hadn't been updated. Many of the categories where there was only few products or were materially close to another category where combined. In summary the old categories were outdated and needed to be re-assessed at the time by management.

# try to detect any false match between sale(dollars) and state bottle retail*bottles_sold
# from the commets above (originally from Iowa gov data portal), it says that Sales/state bottle retail= Bottles sold
# but with the obs I found below, it's not the case...
# some are due to missing values of state bottle retail
# some sales(dollars)/state bottle retail doesn't appear to be integer (aka bottle sold as the data owner said)
# so I will just regard these records for now for time constraint reason
df = df.astype({'Sale (Dollars)': np.float64})
problem_df = df[df['Sale (Dollars)'] != np.round(df['State Bottle Retail'] * df['Bottles Sold'], 2)]
problem_df.head()

# for now just remove all the discrepencies
# but after the presentation, may come back and work more on cleansing data
problem_indices = set(problem_df[['Sale (Dollars)', 'State Bottle Retail', 'Bottles Sold']].index)
df = df[~df.index.isin(problem_indices)]
# calculate the percentage of problem indices over all data
len(problem_indices)/len(df)
#### Converting Data Type as Needed

# remove the decimals for columns 'County Number','Category', and 'Vendor Number'
# these features should be converted to string type as we won't do any calculation on them
df['County Number'] = df['County Number'].astype(str).replace('\.0', '', regex=True)
df['Category'] = df['Category'].astype(str).replace('\.0', '', regex=True)
df['Vendor Number'] = df['Vendor Number'].astype(str).replace('\.0', '', regex=True)

# convert the 'Date' column as datetime and sort the dataframe by date
df['Date'] =pd.to_datetime(df.Date, infer_datetime_format=True)
df = df.sort_values(by='Date').reset_index(drop=True)

# create new columns for month|quarter|year of the date for sales analysis
df['Year_Week'] = df['Date'].dt.to_period('W')
df['Year_Month'] = df['Date'].dt.to_period('M')
df['Year_Quarter'] = df['Date'].dt.to_period('Q')
df['Year'] = df['Date'].dt.to_period('A')
#### Count of Unique Values of Each Column

for column in df.columns:
    df[column] = df[column].apply(lambda x: np.nan if x == '' else x)
    df[column] = df[column].apply(lambda x: np.nan if x == 0.0 else x)

#### <font color='red'>Placeholder - Decide If Need to Fill in Missing Values</font>

# removing all rows with missing values
# df_copy = df.copy()
df_without_null = df[~df.index.isin(list(missing_set))]
df_null = df[df.index.isin(list(missing_set))]
# pickle the dataframe without nulls for future analysis
df_without_null.to_pickle('without_null.pickle')
### <font color='orange'>Explortory Data Analysis</font>
# reload the df_without_null
df_cleaned = pd.read_pickle('without_null.pickle')

# calculate the markup per bottle, markup per transaction, and markup rate for each item
# markup is the difference between 'state bottle cost' and 'state bottle retail', 
# which is the amount that Iowa state alchoholic beverage division makes per bottle of liquor
# markup rate per item is the markup per bottle bdivided by 'state bottle cost'
df_cleaned['Markup Per Bottle'] = df_cleaned['State Bottle Retail'] - df_cleaned['State Bottle Cost']
df_cleaned['Markup Per Transaction'] = df_cleaned['Markup Per Bottle'] * df_cleaned['Bottles Sold']
df_cleaned['Cost Per Transaction'] = df_cleaned['State Bottle Cost'] * df_cleaned['Bottles Sold']
df_cleaned['Markup Rate Per Item'] = round(df_cleaned['Markup Per Bottle']/df_cleaned['State Bottle Cost']*100,2)

# try to find the # of obs of which the unique county names and unique county number don't match
# then need to clean up the data for the county column
print('If the number of unique county names match the number of unique county number? - ', df_cleaned['County Number'].nunique() == df_cleaned['County'].nunique())
df_cleaned['County'] = df_cleaned['County'].str.lower()
sorted(df_cleaned['County'].unique())

# I can see that there are 4 pairs of duplicates due to typo
# 'buena visita vs buena visit', 'cerro gord vs cerro gordo', 'o'brien vs obrien', and 'pottawatta vs pottawattamie'
df_cleaned['County'] = df_cleaned['County'].replace('buena vist','buena vista')
df_cleaned['County'] = df_cleaned['County'].replace('cerro gord','cerro gordo')
df_cleaned['County'] = df_cleaned['County'].replace("o'brien",'obrien')
df_cleaned['County'] = df_cleaned['County'].replace('pottawatta','pottawattamie')

#### Rename Store Names

Many store names are actually under the same brand (e.g., Hy-Vee Food Store and Hy-Vee Drug Store are both Hy-Vee chained stores. I'm going to rename these stores with its actually brand name and analyze data from there

store_names = df_cleaned['Store Name'].apply(lambda x: x.split('/')[0])
store_names_length = store_names.apply(lambda x: len(x))
store_names_shortened = store_names.apply(lambda x: x[:4])
top_15_stores = set(store_names_shortened.value_counts().index.values[:15])
df_cleaned['Shortened Store Name'] = store_names_shortened
top_15_stores_df = df_cleaned[df_cleaned['Shortened Store Name'].isin(top_15_stores)]

top_15_stores_df_list = [pd.DataFrame()]*len(top_15_stores)

for idx, store in enumerate(top_15_stores):
    store_df = top_15_stores_df[top_15_stores_df['Shortened Store Name'] == store]
    top_15_stores_df_list[idx] = store_df
    store_df = None

df_liquor_freq.nlargest(20)
#### Get The Most Profitable Liquor Item Names (with Max) within Transactions of Top 15 Stores
Most profitable liquors are those with highest markup rates. Here I find the highest markup rate with corresponding liquor item names

# pay attention that I only aggregate the max value here
# as Johnathon suggested, I need to calculate sum of sales/ sum of markups/ sum of costs etc., 
# then calculate the markup rate at category level. I'll do that part later
markup_rate_by_alcohol = np.round(top_15_stores_df_master.groupby(by = 'Item Description')['Markup Rate Per Item'].max(), 2)

markup_rate_by_alcohol_list = []

markup_rate_by_alcohol_keys = markup_rate_by_alcohol.index.values
markup_rate_by_alcohol_values = markup_rate_by_alcohol.values

for idx, key in enumerate(markup_rate_by_alcohol_keys):
    key = markup_rate_by_alcohol_keys[idx] 
    value = markup_rate_by_alcohol_values[idx] 
    markup_rate_by_alcohol_list.append((key, value))

source:
# so from the results we can see that the top categories with highest markup rates (at category level)
# are barbados rum, american cocktails, vodka flavored, imported amaretto, root beer schnapps, strawberry schnapps,
# flavored rum, puerto rico&virgin islands rum, canadian whiskies
df_markup = top_15_stores_df_master.groupby(['Category Name']).agg({'Markup Per Transaction':'sum','Cost Per Transaction':'sum'})
df_markup = df_markup.rename(columns={'Markup Per Transaction': 'Markup Sum Per Category', 'Cost Per Transaction': 'Cost Sum Per Category'})
df_markup['Markup Rate Per Category'] = df_markup['Markup Sum Per Category']/df_markup['Cost Sum Per Category']
df_markup.sort_values(by='Markup Rate Per Category', ascending = False)
